page.title: Opinions on the Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy

rev.comment: fixed typos, but it needs a source
rev.diff:
Line 87: Line 87:
[[Hamshahri]], Iran's largest newspaper has announced that it will be holding an "international cartoon contest about the Holocaust" in reaction to the images. Says the papers graphics editor: "The Western papers printed these sacrilegious cartoons on the pretext of freedom of expression, so let's see if they mean what they say and also print these Holocaust cartoons".<ref>{{citenews|date=[[7 February]] [[2006]]|title=Iran to publish Holocaust cartoons|org=NEWS.com.au|url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,10117,18066746-1702,00.html?from=rss}}</ref>
[[Hamshahri]], Iran's largest newspaper has announced that it will be holding an "international cartoon contest about the Holocaust" in reaction to the images. Says the papers graphics editor: "The Western papers printed these sacrilegious cartoons on the pretext of freedom of expression, so let's see if they mean what they say and also print these Holocaust cartoons".<ref>{{citenews|date=[[7 February]] [[2006]]|title=Iran to publish Holocaust cartoons|org=NEWS.com.au|url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,10117,18066746-1702,00.html?from=rss}}</ref>
â
There is one view that Muhammad himself would not have been so angered by these cartoons based on a particular Hadith. The hadith regards an incident in which a stranger started to offend a companinon of the prophet and seeing that the companinon was not affended he insulted Muhammad. As the companinon becamed angered Muhammad left.
+
There is one view, based on a particular Hadith, that Muhammad himself would not have been so angered by these cartoons. The hadith regards an incident in which a stranger started to offend a companion of the prophet; seeing that the companion was not offended, he insulted Muhammad. As the companion becamed angered, Muhammad left.{{fact}}
